title: Karatsu Mokuzuke
text: Japanese tea masters prized the simple, unpretentious beauty of everyday wares produced by Korean émigré potters at the Karatsu kilns on the southern-most island of Kyushu. This small cup-shaped dish, called <I>muko_zuke<I>, was used to serve an appetizer of marinated fish or vegetables. The term <I>muko_zuke<I> describes their placement (<I>zuke<I>) on the opposite side (<I>muko_<I>) of the serving tray--away from the guest. Bowls for rice and soup were placed closer to the guest on the tray. Typical of wares from the Karatsu kilns, this <I>muko_zuke<I> was decorated with casual, rapidly painted designs in iron-oxide brown.
description: squared form, with high walls; small ring foot; milky translucent glaze; stylized depictions of bridges and water, in brown
creditline: Gift of the Friends of the Institute
